questions.text: A patient with fatigue and pallor is found to have severe anemia. You decide to do a PRBC transfusion. What is the cannula size and duration of transfusion?

choices.text: With a 18-20G needle, within 4 hours of receiving at the patient's side
With an 18-20G needle, within 30 minutes of issue from the blood bank
With a 20-22G needle, within 4 hours of receiving at the patient's side
With an 18-20G needle, within 4 hours of issue from the blood bank

questions.solution:
A patient undergoing packed red blood transfusion (PRBC) should receive it with an 18-20G needle within 4 hours of issue from the blood bank.

The guidelines for blood transfusion are as follows.

  • Obtain large-bore intravenous access with an 18 gauge or larger cannula.
  • Each unit should be transfused within 4 hours of issue from the blood bank (removal from controlled temperature storage).
  • A second IV access should be secured in case the patient needs additional IV medications.
  • Normal saline is the only fluid that can be administered with blood products.
  • Red blood cell units left out of controlled temperature storage for more than 30 minutes should not be returned to storage for reissue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who is a known hypertensive comes to the medicine OPD for a regular check-up. He complains of always being anxious. On examination, his BMI is 29 and his BP is 180/100 mmHg. His blood workup shows Hb - 18 g%, and hematocrit - 60%. What condition does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing increased haemoglobin and hematocrit values in an obese, hypertensive and anxious person is highly suggestive of Stress polycythemia or Gaisböck syndrome.

Polycythemia denotes an abnormally high red cell count, usually with a corresponding increase in the haemoglobin level. It may be relative when there is hemoconcentration due to decreased plasma volume, or absolute when there is an increase in the total red cell mass.

Relative polycythemia:

Relative polycythemia results from dehydration, such as occurs with deprivation of water, prolonged vomiting or diarrhoea, or excessive use of diuretics. It is also associated with an obscure condition of unknown aetiology called stress polycythemia, or Gaisböck syndrome. Affected individuals are usually hypertensive, obese, and anxious (“stressed”). In this case there is normal RBC mass but a relative decrease in plasma volume.

Absolute polycythemia:

Absolute polycythemia is primary when it results from an intrinsic abnormality of hematopoietic precursors and secondary when the red cell progenitors are responding to increased levels of erythropoietin.

  • Primary: The most common cause of primary polycythemia is polycythemia vera, a myeloproliferative disorder associated with mutations that lead to erythropoietin-independent growth of red cell progenitors. Much less commonly, primary polycythemia results from familial mutations in the erythropoietin receptor that induce erythropoietin-independent receptor activation.
  • Secondary polycythemia: It may be caused by compensatory or pathologic increases in erythropoietin secretion. Causes of the latter include erythropoietin-secreting tumours and rare, but illustrative inherited defects that lead to the stabilization of HIF-1α, a hypoxia-induced factor that stimulates the transcription of the erythropoietin gene.

questions.text: A 45-year-old old man presented with abdominal pain and slate grey pigmentation in his face and neck. On examination, he was found to have hepatomegaly. The liver biopsy section shows golden-yellow granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes and special staining with Prussian blue is as seen below.  Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Pancreas may show diffuse interstitial fibrosis and parenchymal atrophy leading to diabetes mellitus
Dilated cardiomyopathy due to hemosiderin granules within myocardial fibers
Disabling polyarthritis due to deposition of hemosiderin

questions.solution:
The image shows the Prussian blue-stained section of liver tissue showing extensive hemosiderin deposition stained blue. Parenchymal architecture is normal. The most likely diagnosis is hereditary hemochromatosis. Disabling polyarthritis in hemochromatosis is due to the deposition of Calcium pyrophosphate which damages the articular cartilage, referred to as Pseudogout.

Hemochromatosis is caused by excessive iron absorption, most of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas, followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. When hemochromatosis results from an inherited disorder, it is referred to as hereditary hemochromatosis. The adult form of hemochromatosis is almost always caused by mutations of HFE located on the short arm of chromosome 6. 

Symptoms usually appear in the fourth to fifth decades of life in men and later in women. The principal manifestations of classic hemochromatosis include hepatomegaly, abdominal pain, abnormal skin pigmentation (particularly in sun-exposed areas), deranged glucose homeostasis, or diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of pancreatic islets, cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias, cardiomyopathy), and atypical arthritis.

In some patients, the presenting complaint is hypogonadism. The testes may be small and atrophic, secondary to a derangement in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis resulting in reduced gonadotropin and testosterone levels. 

A significant cause of death is hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: The gross appearance of a liver pictured while conducting an autopsy of a chronic alcoholic is as shown below. This finding is a result of the activation of which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
The gross appearance of the liver showing classic micronodular cirrhosis seen in alcoholic steatofibrosis is a result of the activation of stellate cells.

Stellate cells :

Scarring of the liver (cirrhosis) in which hepatocytes are surrounded by fibrosis (with or without a regenerative response) represents a common endpoint for chronic liver disease. The principal cell type involved in scar deposition in the liver is the hepatic stellate cell. 

Hepatic stellate cells are present in the space of Disse and store lipids, including vitamin A. They are mesenchymal in origin. But in several cases of acute and chronic injury to the liver, these cells are activated and differentiate into highly fibrogenic myofibroblasts.

The activation of stellate cells can be varied and includes the following:

  • Inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α) are produced by Kupffer cells, macrophages, etc.
  • Altered interactions with the extracellular matrix
  • Toxins and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

These activated stellate cells are then converted into myofibroblasts through signals transmitted by platelet-derived growth factor receptor β and by several cytokines (TGF-β, IL-17) and chemokines. Extracellular matrix deposition and scarring commence in the space of Disse. Eventually, the surviving hepatocytes are encircled by fibrous septa and give rise to diffuse scarring (cirrhosis). Hepatocytes replicate in an effort to restore the parenchyma which gives rise to regenerative nodules, a feature seen in most cirrhotic livers.

There are three distinctive, overlapping forms of alcoholic liver injury:

  • Hepatic steatosis (fatty liver)
    • Fatty change is completely reversible if there is abstention from further intake of alcohol.
    • Starts in the centrilobular area
  • Alcoholic (steato) hepatitis
    • Ballooning degeneration and necrosis
    • Mallory–Denk bodies/ Mallory hyaline - These are tangled skeins of intermediate filaments such as keratin 8 and keratin 18 that are partially degraded and ubiquitinated.
    • Neutrophilic reaction
  • Alcoholic steatofibrosis
    • Perisinusoidal fibrosis and sclerosis of the central vein
    • Micronodular/ Laennec cirrhosis
    • Irreversible

Continued damage of the liver with alcohol progresses to portal/ periportal fibrosis, and then to bridging fibrosis and cirrhosis, which is micronodular (“Laennec cirrhosis”) The characteristic diffuse nodularity of the surface is induced by the underlying fibrous scarring.

Other options:

Option B: Kupffer cells are hepatic macrophages, which are responsible for removing cellular and microbial debris from the circulation, and also for secreting cytokines involved in defense.

Option C: Hepatic stem cells are undifferentiated, pluripotential cells and reside around the canals of Hering.

Option D: The endothelial cells are typically flat cells, each with a central nucleus, and they are joined to each other by junctional complexes. Their cytoplasm contains numerous transcytotic vesicles.

questions.text: A surgeon resecting a mass suspicious for malignancy orders a frozen section biopsy. All of the following statements are true about this procedure, except that ___.

choices.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy in breast carcinoma is an example
It is used for detecting positive margins after resection
It is used to confirm suspected metastasis
It gives an immediate definitive diagnosis of the tumor

questions.solution:
A frozen section done during the surgery of a carcinoma breast is not useful for a definitive diagnosis.

A frozen section provides rapid gross or microscopic diagnoses that can guide intra- or peri-operative management of a patient, including identification of an unknown pathologic process and tissue, evaluation of adequacy of margins, and identification of metastases.

A sentinel lymph node is the first node in a regional lymphatic basin that receives lymph flow from the primary tumor. An examination of frozen sections of the sentinel lymph node performed during surgery can guide the surgeon to the appropriate therapy. In patients where there is no tumor involvement of the sentinel node, further axillary dissection can be avoided.
 
The quality of a frozen section slide is inferior to that of routinely processed material, reducing the accuracy and precision of diagnosis. Even though frozen section provides rapid diagnosis, it should not be used to replace paraffin-embedded tissue technique to get a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: Which form of systemic vasculitis is most likely to present with an orbital pseudotumor?
questions.solution: Granulomatosis with polyangitis (Wegener granulomatosis) can lead to orbital pseudotumor and scleritis. This pseudotumor can cause proptosis and vision loss if blood circulation to the eye is compromised by the retrobulbar mass.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
ARPKD is most likely to be associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis.

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is secondary to a mutation of the PKHD1 gene (which encodes a protein called fibrocystin) on chromosome 6p. The severe form manifests in utero or in infancy; milder cases can manifest later in childhood. All affected individuals have some degree of congenital hepatic fibrosis. 50% of affected newborns die in the first few days of life.

ADPKD is usually clinically silent. Many cases remain asymptomatic until the fifth decade of life and are diagnosed incidentally. PKD-1 mutations cause more severe disease than PKD-2 mutations. The following clinical features may be seen in symptomatic patients:

  • Abdominal mass
  • Back or flank pain 
  • Recurrent UTIs - Renal cyst infections by Gram-negative bacteria are common
  • Nephrolithiasis - most commonly uric acid stones
  • Hematuria
  • Cardiac:
    • Hypertension - early feature  
    • Left ventricular hypertrophy
    • Mitral valve prolapse, valvular insufficiency
  • Extra-renal:
    • Intracranial aneurysms
    • Hepatic cysts

As the cysts grow they compress on the surrounding normal tissue which leads to a progressive reduction in the GFR. Eventually, it leads to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) by the fifth decade of life.

questions.text: Which of the following acute-phase reactants is a strong, independent marker of risk for myocardial infarction and peripheral arterial disease?
questions.solution:
Plasma C-reactive protein (CRP) is a strong, independent marker of risk for myocardial infarction, stroke, peripheral arterial disease, and sudden cardiac death, even among apparently healthy individuals.

  • CRP is an acute-phase reactant synthesized primarily by the liver.
  • CRP expression is increased by a number of inflammatory mediators, particularly IL-6.
  • CRP is a useful marker for gauging the effects of risk reduction measures, such as smoking cessation, weight loss, exercise, and statins; each one of these reduces CRP levels.

questions.text: A woman presented with the following lesion on her face. All are favorable prognostic factors in this condition except _________
questions.solution:
The absence of regression confers a favourable prognosis.

Regression is a phenomenon in which the host immune response, via tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes, attacks the primary melanocytic tumor cells and leaves behind a fibrotic component. It describes an area where it appears there had been melanoma cells but these have been destroyed by the immune system and replaced with inflammatory cells or fibrosis. This phenomenon obliterates the tumor margin and increases the likelihood of incomplete excision. As a result, regression has been considered a poor prognostic factor in melanoma. The presence of regression could indicate metastasis.

Determinants of a more favorable prognosis in melanoma include:

  • thinner tumor depth
  • no or very few mitoses (< 1 per mm2)
  • a brisk tumor infiltrating lymphocyte response
  • the absence of regression
  • lack of ulceration
  • absence of metastases in the sentinel lymph node

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.solution:

questions.text:
A female baby presented with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension on the 5th day of life. The mother informs that the child has not passed meconium yet. Barium enema of the patient shows the following. A rectal biopsy is taken to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?
  1. The disease is more common in females
  2. The rectum is always affected
  3. Disease limited to the rectosigmoid is termed short-segment disease
  4. The aganglionic region may have a grossly normal or dilated appearance
  5. Chagas disease shares the same pathophysiology as this disease
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium enema image showing a dilated right colon is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. Among the given statements, 2,3 and 5 are true.

Hirschsprung disease is also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon. The premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum produces aganglionosis of the distal intestinal segment. This causes functional obstruction of the affected bowel and proximal dilation. Diagnosis requires documenting the absence of ganglion cells within the affected segment.

Heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase RET account for the majority of familial and sporadic Hirschsprung disease cases. There is an association between Downs syndrome and Hirschsprung disease as well. The disease is more common in males, but, when present in females, the affected aganglionic segment tends to be longer.

Diagnosis : 

Histologic confirmation that ganglion cells are absent within the affected segment through hematoxylin and eosin-stained sections or immunohistochemical stains for acetylcholinesterase.

Based on the segments affected, they are classified into -

  • Short-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease limited to the rectosigmoid segment
  • Long-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease having proximal extension beyond the rectosigmoid segment

The rectum is always affected, but the length of the additional involved segments varies widely. In most cases, the abnormality extends to the sigmoid colon, but in severe cases, the entire colon may be involved.

The aganglionic region may have a grossly normal or contracted appearance. The normally innervated proximal colon undergoes progressive dilation and may become massively distended (congenital megacolon) as a result of the distal obstruction.

Causes of acquired megacolon :

  • Chagas disease (same pathophysiology as Hirschsprung)
  • Obstruction by a neoplasm or inflammatory stricture
  • A complication of ulcerative colitis
  • Visceral myopathy
  • Association with psychosomatic disorders

questions.text:
Match the components of angiogenesis to their respective actions:

Component

 Action
1. Vascular endothelial growth factor a. Smooth muscle cells recruiter
2.Fibroblast growth factor-2 b. Formation of vascular lumen
3. Angiopoietin c. Suppression of endothelial proliferation
4. Platelet-derived growth factor d. Proliferation of endothelial cells
5. Transforming growth factor - β e. Structural maturation
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Component Action
1. Vascular endothelial growth factor b. Formation of vascular lumen
2. Fibroblast growth factor-2  d. Proliferation of endothelial cells
3. Angiopoietin e. Structural maturation
4. Platelet-derived growth factor a. Smooth muscle cells recruiter
5. Transforming growth factor - β c. Suppression of endothelial proliferation

 

Angiogenesis refers to the formation of new blood vessels from existing ones. It aids in wound healing, establishing collateral circulation in ischemia, and helps in increasing tumor size. It involves various signaling pathways, cell-cell interactions, extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins, and tissue enzymes.

Mechanisms of angiogenesis are as follows:

  • VEGF: Promotes vasodilation by nitric oxide synthesis and subsequent formation of a vascular lumen. 
  • FGF (FGF-2): Induces proliferation of endothelial cells. It increases the migration of macrophages and fibroblasts to the site of injury. It also stimulates the migration of epithelial cells to cover epidermal wounds.
  • Angiopoietins 1 and 2: They are growth factors that are involved in the structural maturation of new vessels.
  • New vessels are stabilized by pericytes, smooth muscle cells, and by the deposition of connective tissue.
  • PDGF recruits smooth muscle cells.
  • TGF-β enhances the production of ECM proteins. TGF-β also suppresses endothelial proliferation and migration. 

Angiogenesis is regulated by the Notch signaling pathway. ECM proteins aid in angiogenesis by providing scaffolds for vessel growth. Matrix metalloproteinases degrade ECM to allow remodeling and extension of the vessel.

Related Pearl: Factors Influencing Healing

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes to the hospital due to a lump in the breast. She is diagnosed to have breast cancer. A Her-2/neu IHC score of +2 is given for this patient. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
In a patient with breast cancer having a Her-2/neu IHC score of +2, the next step is to do FISH for gene amplification.

This should be performed in all cases of breast tumors with an immunohistochemistry (IHC) score of 2+.

Her-2/neu IHC interpretation: 

  • 1+ = Negative
  • 2+ = Equivocal-> FISH is done to differentiate whether the tumor cells are positive or negative for Her-2 Neu expression.
  • 3+ = +ve Her 2 Neu. (Circumferential complete membrane staining in >10% of tumor cells)

Other options:

Option A: IHC score of +1 indicates Her-2/neu Negative
Option C: Trastuzumab is used in Her-2/Neu Positive breast carcinoma
Option D: PET scan is done only in cases where metastasis is suspected. The best next step in this patient is FISH for gene amplification

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding atrial myxomas?

choices.text: Stellate or globular cells can be seen
More commonly seen  in the right atrium
Most common primary tumor of the adult heart
Most common site of origin is fossa ovalis in the atrial septum

questions.solution:
Myxomas are the most common primary tumor of the heart in adults and atrial myxoma is most commonly located in the left atrium.

Myxomas are benign neoplasms that arise from primitive multipotent mesenchymal cells. 90 percent of myxoma are located in the atria, sporadic, and are usually single. The left-to-right ratio of the myxoma is approximately 4:1. The most common site of origin is fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. 

They mainly present with symptoms that mimic mitral valve disease. A characteristic low pitched sound, a "tumor plop", is heard on auscultation during early or mid diastole as a result of the impact from the tumor against the mitral valve or ventricular wall.

They also present with constitutional symptoms like fever, cachexia, and malaise due to the elevation of cytokines like interleukin 6. 

Myxomas are composed of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. Peculiar vessel-like or gland-like structures are characteristically seen along with hemorrhage and mononuclear inflammation.

The image below shows an abundant amorphous extracellular matrix containing scattered multinucleate myxoma cells in various groupings, including abnormal vessel-like formations.

Mobile tumors exert a “wrecking-ball” effect, causing damage to the valve leaflets.

Myoma can be sessile or pedunculated lesions. They appear as a globular hard mass mottled with hemorrhage arising from the fossa ovalis as shown below.

Transesophageal/ Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is the diagnostic investigation.

The below image of TTE shows a mass in the left atrium suggestive of atrial myxoma.

Surgical excision is done regardless of the tumor size.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of primary hemostasis after the exposure of von Willebrand factor (vWF) and collagen in sequence.
  1. Platelet recruitment
  2. Platelet aggregation
  3. Shape change
  4. Release of secretory granules
  5. Platelet adhesion and activation
questions.solution:
The option showing the correct sequence of primary hemostasis is 5, 3, 4, 1, 2

Primary hemostasis:

Primary hemostasis is the stage in the process of normal hemostasis where the platelet plug is formed. The exposure of von Willebrand factor (vWF) and collagen following the disruption of the endothelium, promotes platelet adherence and activation. These platelets undergo a change in shape in order to increase the surface area as a result of the activation. They turn from small discs to flat plate-like structures with spiky projections. This is followed by the secretion of granules such as adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and thrombocane A2 (TxA2) which aid in the recruitment of additional platelets. These undergo aggregation to form a primary platelet plug.

The process of hemostasis is arteriolar vasoconstriction → platelet plug → tissue factor release → fibrin deposit.

Normal hemostasis:

  1. Arteriolar vasoconstriction: After vascular injury, local neurohumoral factors induce transient vasoconstriction.
  2. Primary hemostasis: Platelets bind via glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) receptors to von Willebrand factor (vWF) on exposed extracellular matrix (ECM) and are activated, undergoing a shape change and granule release. Released adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and thromboxane A2 (TxA2) induce additional platelet aggregation through platelet GpIIb-IIIa receptor binding to fibrinogen and form the primary hemostatic plug.
  3. Secondary hemostasis: Local activation of the coagulation cascade (involving tissue factor and platelet phospholipids) results in fibrin polymerization, “cementing” the platelets into a definitive secondary hemostatic plug.
  4. Clot stabilization and resorption: Counter-regulatory mechanisms, mediated by tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA, a fibrinolytic product) and thrombomodulin, confine the hemostatic process to the site of injury.

questions.text: A 3-year-old female child presented with an abnormal polypoid mass protruding from the vagina. Histopathological analysis showed malignant embryonal rhabdomyoblasts. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Pleomorphic variant commonly occurs in children less than 5 years
Immunohistochemistry of the cells show Desmin positivity
Botryoid variant carries the best prognosis
This tumour has local, lymphatic and hematogenous spread

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and biopsy findings are suggestive of Rhabdomyosarcoma. The Pleomorphic variant of Rhabdomyosarcoma predominantly occurs in adults. 

Rhabdomyosarcomas are malignant mesenchymal tumors with skeletal muscle differentiation in childhood and adolescence that may occur at virtually any anatomic site but are usually found in the head and neck (25%), genitourinary tract (24%), extremities (19%) and orbit (9%). Retroperitoneum and other sites account for the remainder of primary sites.

It is classified into three subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, and pleomorphic.

  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Rhabdomyoblasts with visible cross-striations may be present. Sarcoma botryoids is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina with cambium layer. It commonly affects children below 5 years of age.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma has a network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli.
  •  Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults. 

Clinically, the tumor is usually aggressive, with unilateral proptosis when the orbit is involved. Swelling and redness of the overlying skin, diplopia may be present.

Immunohistochemistry is positive for desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1, and vimentin.

Rhabdomyosarcoma shows a strong tendency for local invasion, local recurrence, and hematogenous and lymphatic metastases.

Treatment involves surgical resection and chemotherapy, with or without radiotherapy. The best prognosis is for the botryoid variant while the pleomorphic variant has the worst prognosis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female presents with a unilateral bloody nipple discharge. On examination, a small, palpable mass beneath the areola is noted. A core needle biopsy is performed, and the histopathology report is as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of unilateral bloody nipple discharge with a palpable mass beneath the areola and histopathology showing a central fibrovascular core with papillae arborizing within the lumen are suggestive of a solitary intraductal papilloma.  

Intraductal papilloma is a benign, proliferative breast disorder without atypia. It can be solitary or multiple (papillomatosis). Most commonly seen in premenopausal women.

Option A. Ductal carcinoma in situ: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a neoplastic proliferation of epithelial cells limited by the basement membrane. It involves the ducts and lobules. It is not associated with a loss of E-cadherin expression. It typically presents as a suspicious area on a mammogram rather than a palpable mass with bloody discharge.

Option C. Lobular carcinoma in situ: Histologically, LCIS consists of a monomorphic population of cells with oval or round nuclei and small nucleoli involving ducts and lobules. Mucin-positive signet ring cells are commonly present. The histological image is given below:

Option D. Fibroadenoma: This is a benign breast tumor that is usually firm, rubbery, and mobile. They occur in women in their 20s and 30s, and they are frequently multiple and bilateral. Histology shows delicate and often myxoid stroma that resembles normal intralobular stroma. questions.text: The prothrombin time of a patient with menorrhagia is being estimated. Which factor initiates the clotting pathway being tested here?
questions.solution:
The prothrombin time tests the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. This is initiated by the tissue factor.

To test the extrinsic pathway, clotting is initiated in the laboratory by adding a source of tissue factor which combines with factor VIIa. It is the major initiator of coagulation in vivo and is amplified by feedback loops involving thrombin.

To test the intrinsic pathway, clotting is initiated in the laboratory by adding phospholipids, calcium, or a negatively charged substance such as glass beads. The intrinsic pathway is kicked off in the body by thrombin.

A 55-year-old male patient came to the physician due to chronic fatigue. On examination, generalized painless lymphadenopathy is noted. Biopsy of the lymph node is done showing findings in the picture. On immunohistochemistry, the lymphoma cells expressed CD5, CD20, and cyclin D1. Lab findings are given below. Which among the following is the cell of origin in this patient's pathology?

Lab findings:

Hb: 10gm/dl

TLC: 1,40,00/mm3

Platelet: 2,26,000/mm3
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing generalized painless lymphadenopathy, immunotyping showing CD5, CD20 and cyclin D1 with histopathology showing irregular nuclear contours of the medium-sized lymphoma cells and the presence of pink histiocytes is suggestive of Mantle Cell Lymphoma which has naive B cells as its cell of origin.

Mantle cell lymphomas have an (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 that leads to overexpression of cyclin D1.

Mantle cell lymphoma is an uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that usually presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life and shows a male predominance. The tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers.

The most common presentation is painless lymphadenopathy. Symptoms related to the involvement of the spleen (present in ~50% of cases) and gut are also common. Frequent sites of extranodal involvement include the bone marrow, spleen, liver, and gut. Occasionally, mucosal involvement of the small bowel or colon produces polyp-like lesions (lymphomatoid polyposis). The prognosis is poor; the median survival is only 3 to 4 years.

Histopathology shows nodular Mantle Cell Lymphoma with irregular nuclear contours of the medium-sized lymphoma cells and the presence of pink histiocytes.

Typically, the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours. Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centers are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively. In most cases the nuclear chromatin is condensed, nucleoli are inconspicuous, and the cytoplasm is scant. 

Immunophenotype. Mantle cell lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1. These cells are CD19+, CD20+, CD21+, C22+, CD23-, CD 5+.

Other Options:

Germinal center B cell / Post germinal centre B cell is the cell of origin in Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

Germinal center B cell is also the cell of origin for Burkitt's lymphoma and Follicular lymphoma.

Memory B cells are the cells of origin in Extranodal marginal zone lymphoma, Hairy cell leukemia, and in some cases Small lymphocytic lymphoma/chronic lymphocytic leukemia (SLL/CLL).

questions.text: After an episode of viral hepatitis, which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the regeneration of the lost hepatocytes?

choices.text: Decreased apoptosis at G1-M part of cell cycle
Hepatocyte recruitment from G0 to enter cell cycle
Hepatocytes undergoing terminal differentiation as they exit the cell cycle

questions.solution:
Liver parenchyma is an example of stable tissue. It is made up of cells that are normally in the G0 phase (quiescent) of the cell cycle and are not proliferating. However, they are capable of entering the cell cycle and proliferating in response to injury.

Different tissues have different intrinsic proliferative capacity, which determines their ability to repair themselves. 

Labile tissues - cells are constantly being lost and must be continually replaced by new cells that are derived from tissue stem cells (option C). These tissues can readily regenerate after injury as long as the pool of stem cells is preserved.

  • Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow
  • Basal layers of many surface epithelia, such as squamous epithelia of the skin, oral cavity
  • Cuboidal epithelia of the ducts draining exocrine organs e.g., salivary glands, biliary tract
  • Columnar epithelium of the gastrointestinal tract, uterus, and fallopian tubes
  • Transitional epithelium of the urinary tract

Stable tissues - made up of cells that are normally in the G0 stage of the cell cycle and hence not proliferating, but they are capable of dividing in response to injury.

  • Parenchyma of most solid organs, such as liver, kidney, and pancreas
  • Endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells

Permanent tissues - The cells in these tissues are considered to be terminally differentiated and nonproliferative in postnatal life. Injury to these tissues is irreversible and results in a scar, because the cells cannot regenerate.

  • Majority of neurons
  • Cardiac muscle cells

Other options:

Option A: Decreased apoptosis would not lead to the regeneration of the lost hepatocytes.

Option D: Hepatocytes do not undergo terminal differentiation as they exit the cell cycle since they are stable tissue.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with a painless testicular lump. A high inguinal orchidectomy was done because of a suspicion of malignancy. Histopathological examination shows uniform oval cells with a watery-appearing cytoplasm and a large, central nucleus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a testicular mass that on histopathological examination shows uniform oval cells with watery-appearing cytoplasm and a large, central nucleus points to the diagnosis of seminoma. 

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor. A similar tumor arises in the ovary, where it is called dysgerminoma, and also in the CNS, usually in the midline structures such as the pineal gland, where it is called germinoma. On gross appearance, the testis has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Tunica albuginea is not usually penetrated.

 

The histological examination shows sheets of uniform cells with clear or watery-appearing cytoplasm with a large central nucleus, with one or two prominent nucleoli, contributing to the fried egg appearance. The cells have varying amounts of glycogen. These sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa, containing lymphocytic infiltrate. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin.


Other options:

Option B: Teratoma is a tumor that comprises components from all three layers of germ cells such as ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm. On histopathology, collections of differentiated cells is seen in a myxoid stroma. This includes neural tissue, muscle bundles, islands of cartilage and squamous epithelium lined epidermis-like structures with appendages. 

Option C: Granulosa cell tumors are a subset of ovarian tumors composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells in a developing follicle. On histopathological examination, the tumor cells are arranged in cords, strands, or sheets punctuated by Call-Exner bodies. These are small, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material.

Option D: On histopathological examination of a sertoli cell tumor, cells that are arranged in distinctive trabeculae are seen. They tend to form cord-like structures and tubules.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man who has been diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) comes for a follow-up visit when he is found to be anemic. Bone marrow biopsy show marrow fibrosis. Peripheral blood smear findings include occasional myelocytes, a few tear-drop red blood cells (RBCs), and two nucleated RBCs per 100 white cells. Erythrocytes are normochromic and normocytic. What is the most common cause of this form of anemia?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) in the spent phase (marrow fibrosis and cytopenia) is highly suggestive of myelophthisic anemia. The most common cause is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and prostate. 

Points in favor of the diagnosis:

  • Myelocytes + nucleated RBCs = leukoerythroblastic image
  • Presence of tear-drop cells 
  • Myeloproliferative neoplasm in the spent phase of the disease presents with this anemic picture.

Myelophthisic anemia: It is a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal marrow elements. The most common cause is metastatic cancer. The metastasis can be from carcinomas of the breast, lung, and prostate. Apart from these, granulomatous diseases and myeloproliferative neoplasms can also cause myelophthisic anemia. 

Blood picture and marrow findings:

Peripheral blood smear usually shows a normocytic and normochromic form of anemia. A characteristic leukoerythroblastic smear aids with diagnosis. The morphology of the circulating erythrocyte is highly abnormal, which could be nucleated RBCs, teardrops, and shape distortions. An elevated WBC count mimicking a leukemoid reaction is sometimes seen, with circulating myelocytes, promyelocytes, and myeloblasts. Giant size platelets are often seen with thrombocytosis. Bone marrow tap is characteristically dry.

questions.text: False statement regarding carotid body tumours is -

choices.text: The chief cells stain for CD56
They are composed of nests of cells
The stromal cells are positive for S-100

questions.solution:
Carotid body tumors are parasympathetic paragangliomas.

The carotid body tumors are usually less than 6 cm in diameter and arise around the bifurcation of the common carotid artery. The tumor is red-pink to brown colored, and the microscopic features show nests (zellballen), of round to oval chief cells with abundant, clear or granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm and uniform, round to ovoid nuclei, surrounded by delicate vascular septae. There is scanty cellular pleomorphism and mitoses. The chief cells stain positive for chromogranin, synaptophysin, neuron-specific enolase, CD56, and CD57. There is a supporting network of spindle-shaped stromal cells called sustentacular cells that stain positive for S-100. Electron microscopy shows well-demarcated neuroendocrine granules.

Paragangliomas are neuroendocrine cell tumors arising from sympathetic or parasympathetic ganglia. Sympathetic paraganglioma secretes catecholamines whilst parasympathetic are silent. Adrenal medullary pheochromocytomas are the most common paraganglioma. Around 70% of extra-adrenal paragangliomas occur in the head and neck. 

Paragangliomas typically develop in two locations. Paravertebral paraganglia (organ of Zuckerkandl) have sympathetic connections and stain positively for chromaffin, as they produce catecholamines whereas Paraganglia related to the great vessels of the head and neck, especially the aorticopulmonary chain, including the carotid bodies (carotid body tumor), aortic bodies, jugulotympanic ganglia ( glomus tympanicum or jugulare), the vagus nerve, and clusters located around the oral cavity, nose, nasopharynx, larynx, and orbit. These have parasympathetic innervation and do not usually produce catecholamines.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain and melena. On endoscopy, a bleeding gastric mass with irregular borders was identified along the greater curvature of the stomach. Microscopy is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a specific marker for the tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological picture showing spindle-shaped tumor cells are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), for which CD 117 is the specific marker. 

GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, with the most common site being the stomach. The tumor arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.

Most GISTs occur due to gain-of-function mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase KIT (~75%) or PDGRF-ɑ (~8%). 

The tumor peaks at 60 years of age. It is often associated with the Carney triad, a nonhereditary condition characterized by GIST, paraganglioma, and pulmonary chondroma. GIST also has a higher incidence in individuals with neurofibromatosis I.

Patients typically present with anemia (due to blood loss caused by mucosal ulceration) and symptoms of mass effect. However, GISTs may also be discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery.

Microscopically, GIST can be of two patterns:

  1. Spindle cell type: The tumor is composed of thin elongated cells.
  2. Epitheloid type: The tumor is composed of plump epithelial-like cells.

Mixed patterns may also be seen.

The most useful immunohistochemical marker is KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells, along with DOG1.

The prognosis depends on tumor size, mitotic index, and location (GISTs arising in the stomach are less aggressive than those arising in the small intestine). Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-week-old baby to the pediatrics OPD, worried about a pink-colored lesion present on the abdominal wall which has been growing in size since birth. There is no bleeding from the lesion. A histopathological examination of the lesion was done, as shown below. Which internal organ is this lesion most commonly related to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with a pink-colored lesion presenting at birth and growing in size with histopathology showing proliferation of small blood vessels (endothelial lining with RBCs in lumen) suggests capillary hemangioma. Nearly 1/3rd of all internal hemangiomas occur in the liver.

The most common type of hemangioma is capillary hemangioma.

Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors of infancy and childhood. They are of the following types:

  • Capillary hemangiomas: 
    • They are the most common type.
    • They occur in the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and mucous membranes of the oral cavities and lips as well as in the liver, spleen, and kidneys
    • On histology, they show thin-walled capillaries with scant stroma.
  • Juvenile hemangiomas/strawberry type hemangiomas of the newborn are extremely common. They arise in the skin and grow rapidly for a few months, and usually regress completely by the age of 7 years.
  • Cavernous hemangiomas:
    • They are composed of large, dilated vascular channels; are more infiltrative; frequently involve deep structures; and do not spontaneously regress.
    • On histologic examination, the mass is sharply delineated but unencapsulated and composed of large, cavernous blood-filled vascular spaces, separated by connective tissue stroma.
    • They commonly show intravascular thrombosis with associated dystrophic calcification
    • Brain hemangiomas cause symptoms related to compression of adjacent tissue or rupture.
    • They form a component of von Hippel-Lindau disease in which vascular lesions are commonly found in the cerebellum, brain stem, retina, pancreas, and liver
  • Pyogenic granulomas 
    • They are capillary hemangiomas that present as rapidly growing red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or oral mucosa.
    • They bleed easily and are often ulcerated.
    • Lesions may develop after trauma, reaching a size of 1 to 2 cm within a few weeks.
    • Treatment is curettage and cautery

questions.text: Researchers from an immunology lab describe a heterodimeric molecule called human leukocyte antigens (HLA). It helps in antigen recognition by T-cells for which of the following antigens?

In humans, the MHC molecules are called human leukocyte antigens (HLA) because they were initially detected on leukocytes by the binding of antibodies. The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on a small segment of chromosome 6. questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a persistent cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, chest pain, and dyspnea. He is a chronic smoker. On evaluation, a chest x-ray revealed a mass in his right lung and a biopsy of the mass revealed the following picture. Blood examination revealed leukocytosis with no tumor markers. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is large cell carcinoma of the lung.

The given clinical features, with the absence of tumor markers, leukocytosis, and the histopathological image showing large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and a moderate cytoplasm point to the diagnosis of large cell carcinoma of the lung. 

Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial tumor. Typical cytologic features of other forms of lung cancer are absent. This type of lung cancer does not express any of the tumor markers associated with adenocarcinoma (TTF-1, napsin A) or squamous cell carcinoma (p40, p63). On microscopy, the features described above are observed.

Tumor-related leukocytosis is commonly seen as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with large cell carcinoma of the lung.

Option B - Small cell carcinomas are highly malignant tumors with a strong association with cigarette smoking. Histopathological examination shows relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin in a salt-and-pepper pattern, and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli.

Azzopardi effect is the basophilic staining of vessel walls due to DNA residue deposited from necrotic tumor cells, as seen below:


Option D - Squamous cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor associated with smoking. Histopathological examination is characterized by the presence of keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinization is seen as squamous pearls or individual cells with markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is a high mitotic activity in poorly differentiated tumors.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about the direct Coombs test.

choices.text: Detects complement on patient's red cells
Detects antibodies on patient's red cells
Foreign red cells with known antigenicity used
Unbound antibodies in patient's sample are removed

questions.solution:
Foreign red cells with known antigenicity are used in the indirect Coomb's test, not the direct Coomb's test.
 
In the direct Coomb's test or direct antiglobulin test, the patient's red blood cells are mixed with a serum that contains antibodies against human immunoglobulin or complement. If agglutination occurs, it indicates that either immunoglobulin or complement is present on the surface of the patient's red cells. It is used in the diagnosis of immunohemolytic anemia, as it detects the presence of complements or antibodies on the red blood cells. 
 
The principle of the direct Coomb's test is to detect antibodies that are directly bound to the red cells. This can be done by washing a collected blood sample in saline to remove the unbound antibodies that can confound the result.
 
In the indirect Coomb's test or indirect antiglobulin test, foreign red cells with known antigenicity are added to the patient's serum. Antiglobulin reagent is then added and is observed for agglutination. Indirect Coomb's test detects unbound antibodies to red cells, which may be present in the patient’s serum.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with headache, seizures, and focal neurological deficit. Imaging shows a tumor in the right frontal lobe and the histological section of the resected tumor is shown below. According to the WHO grading of brain tumors, this tumor belongs to ______.
questions.solution:
The clinical history and histological image are suggestive of glioblastoma multiforme and it corresponds to WHO grade IV brain tumor.

The given histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudo-palisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, which are characteristic of glioblastoma.

It affects people usually in the sixth or seventh decade. These tumors may arise de novo or may result from a malignant transformation of lower-grade astrocytomas. Mutations of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH), PTEN, and epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene are implicated in the pathogenesis.

They preferentially spread along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the butterfly glioma, involving the contralateral hemisphere. 

Clinically, patients present with headaches, seizures due to raised intracranial pressure, or focal neurologic deficits, depending upon the site involved. 

Grossly, glioblastomas are found to infiltrate the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have grayish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages. Microscopically, they are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity. Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic. They exhibit pseudopalisading—dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis.

Radiologically, glioblastomas appear as a large ring-enhancing heterogeneous mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema that crosses the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. The surrounding edema may be interspersed with infiltrating tumor cells. The tumor may show partial or complete enhancement on contrast study. 

Standard treatment includes surgery followed by a combination of radiotherapy and chemotherapy with temozolomide following surgical resection. Bevacizumab, which is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) antibody, may be used in the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma. 

According to the WHO classification of CNS diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows:

    • About 90% of the cases
    • Primary or de novo glioblastoma
    • Over 55 years of age

2. Glioblastoma, IDH - mutant type:

    • About 10% of the cases
    • Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma
    • Arises in younger patients

3. Glioblastoma, NOS, where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with fever, sore throat, polyarthralgia, erythema marginatum, and chest pain. A rapid streptococcal antigen is found to be positive. Physical examination is remarkable for a loud friction rub. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. Serous pericarditis is seen in acute rheumatic fever.

  • Serous pericarditis:
    • It is seen in rheumatic fever, SLE, systemic scleroderma, tumors, uremia, viral infection, or tuberculosis

    • Tuberculosis or malignant neoplasm (from lung or breast)
    • Can also be seen following cardiac surgery
  • Caseous pericarditis: 
    • Almost always tubercular in origin

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes presents with abdominal distension and frothy urine. Lab tests reveal a urine protein level of 5g in 24 hours. A kidney biopsy was taken for an accurate diagnosis. Which of the following is not typically associated with the disease condition?

choices.text: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane

questions.solution:
The patient’s presentation and lab findings are suggestive of diabetic nephropathy, a common complication of long-standing diabetes. Renal mesangial atrophy is not typically associated with the disease condition. It usually involves mesangial expansion rather than atrophy. 

Diabetic nephropathy typically involves several characteristic histopathological changes in the kidneys which include:

  • Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane: This is a hallmark feature of diabetic nephropathy. Hyperglycemia leads to the accumulation of advanced glycation end products, which causes the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). This structural change is one of the earliest detectable abnormalities in diabetic nephropathy.
  • Renal hypertrophy: Renal hypertrophy is commonly seen in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy. It results from increased glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and hyperfiltration associated with hyperglycemia. This compensatory response eventually leads to damage and scarring of the kidney tissues.
  • Renal mesangial expansion: The expansion of the mesangium is due to the accumulation of extracellular matrix and it correlates with the clinical manifestations of diabetic nephropathy. This expansion in mesangial matrix is associated with the development of mesangial sclerosis
  • Nodular glomerulosclerosis: Also known as Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules, this is a characteristic feature of advanced diabetic nephropathy. These nodules are spherical, hyaline masses that form in the mesangium and are indicative of chronic, severe damage due to long-term diabetes.

questions.text: Which of the following phenomena is associated with dysregulated nutrient sensing?
questions.solution:
Dysregulated nutrient sensing is involved in the mechanism of cellular ageing.

Cellular ageing is caused by a steady loss in cellular function and viability caused by hereditary defects, as well as the buildup of cellular and molecular damage induced by external forces.

Mechanisms involved in cellular ageing include:

  1. DNA damage and defective DNA repair mechanisms.
  2. Replicative senescence - the terminal nondividing state that occurs in all normal cells after a certain number of divisions. It includes telomere attrition and tumour suppressor gene activation.
  3. Defective protein homeostasis involves the maintenance of correctly folded proteins and the destruction of misfolded, damaged proteins via the autophagy-lysosome and ubiquitin-proteasome systems
  4. Dysregulated nutrient sensing- caloric restriction increases longevity.
Nutrient sensing exemplified by caloric restriction, counteracts ageing by decreasing insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) signalling intensity and increasing sirtuins.
Attenuation of IGF-1 signalling leads to reduced cellular damage by decreasing the cell growth rate and metabolism. An increase in sirtuins activates DNA repair enzymes through deacylation, promoting genomic integrity and also contributes to the metabolic adaptations of calorie restriction.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with a rapidly growing lesion near her right ear lobule.  A biopsy from this lesion showed malignant cells as shown below. The immunohistochemical staining was positive for CK-20. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario along with the image showing merkel cells is suggestive of Merkel cell carcinoma. The image shows Merkel cell carcinoma composed of uniform small round cells having granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm. These cells are located in epithelial basal cell layer and have neuroendocrine and mechanoreceptor functions.

Merkel cell carcinoma is a rare and aggressive neuroendocrine tumor of the skin, most commonly found in white men and diagnosed at a mean age of 70 years. A rapidly growing, flesh-colored papule or plaque characterizes the disease. About 80% of the cases are seen associated with Merkel cell polyomavirus. Regional lymph nodes can be involved in some cases and half of the patients are prone to develop systemic disease. CK-20 is a specific marker for Merkel cell carcinoma. treatment involves wide local excision of the tumor.

Other options:

Option A: Basal cell carcinoma histopathology shows basal cells arranged in palisiding pattern.

Option B: Squamous cell carcinoma are composed of polygonal cells arranged in lobules and consist of multiple areas of keratinistion

Option C: Malignant melanoma consists of red eosinophilic nucleoli with peripheral covering of chromatin in the nuclear membrane which gives a dark pigment.

questions.text: Which one of the following tumors is most likely to be associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis?
questions.solution:
Cholangiocarcinoma is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC): It is characterized by fibrosing cholangitis that produces concentric “onion-skin” fibrosis in portal areas. It is highly associated with chronic ulcerative colitis. Abnormal development of the biliary tract may lead to several abnormalities, including von Meyenburg’s complex (small bile duct hamartomas near normal portal tracts) and Caroli’s disease, which is characterized by segmental dilation of the larger intrahepatic bile ducts. There is an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, a malignancy of bile ducts, in patients with PSC.

questions.text: A 56-year-old HIV patient presents with productive cough with blood-stained sputum, evening rise of temperature, and weight loss for 3 weeks. His chest X-ray is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most frequent extrapulmonary presentation of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the gross image is suggestive of primary tuberculosis. Lymphadenitis is the most frequent presentation of extrapulmonary tuberculosis. It usually occurs in the cervical region and is termed scrofula.

Primary tuberculosis:

Primary tuberculosis almost always begins in the lungs. Inhaled bacilli are implanted in the distal airspaces (not proximal) of the lower part of the upper lobe or the upper part of the lower lobe, usually close to the pleura. An area of gray-white inflammation with consolidation develops which is 1-1.5 cms in size known as the Ghon focus. The center of this focus usually undergoes caseous necrosis.

Bacilli either free or within phagocytes drain to regional lymph nodes where caseous necrosis is noted as well. The presence of parenchymal disease and nodal involvement is termed Ghon's complex. This undergoes progressive fibrosis as a result of the cell-mediated immune response, often followed by calcifications that are radiologically visible.

Hematogenous and lymphatic spread is present in the first few weeks of infection which is controlled by cell-mediated immunity in 95% of the cases. Sites of active involvement are marked by a characteristic granulomatous inflammatory reaction that forms both caseating and noncaseating tubercles. A fibroblastic rim punctuated by lymphocytes encloses the granulomas. Multinucleated giant cells are present in the granulomas.

Isolated tuberculosis - This appears in any of the organs or tissues seeded hematogenously and may be the presenting manifestation. Organs commonly involved are:

  • Meninges (tuberculous meningitis)
  • Kidneys (renal tuberculosis)
  • Adrenals (formerly an important cause of Addison disease),
  • Bones (osteomyelitis)
  • Fallopian tubes (salpingitis)
  • Vertebrae (Pott disease).  Paraspinal “cold” abscesses in these patients may track along tissue planes and present as an abdominal or pelvic mass.

Lymphadenitis is the most frequent presentation of extrapulmonary tuberculosis. It usually occurs in the cervical region and is termed scrofula.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the infarct shown in the image?

choices.text: This is an example of coagulative necrosis
Seen in organs which lack an end-arterial circulation
Sepsis is usually absent in this type

questions.solution:
The image shows a splenic infarct that appears white, wedge-shaped, and bland in nature. It is seen in organs with an end-arterial circulation (i.e. organs that lack collateral circulation)

An infarct is an area of localized coagulative necrosis. They may be red (hemorrhagic) or white (anemic) based on color. Based on the presence or absence of infection, they may be septic or bland, respectively. Splenic infarcts are usually white, bland, wedge-shaped, and subcapsular in location.

The spleen is an organ with end-arterial circulation. The occlusion of a major splenic artery or any of its branches causes the infarct. Vascular occlusion leads to an infarct due to the lack of collateral blood supply. Common sites where emboli lodges are the kidney, brain, and spleen.

Splenic infarcts are usually bland unless it occurs in a patient with infectious endocarditis. In such cases, septic infarcts are common. There is suppurative necrosis due to the presence of microbes in the necrotic tissue. The infarct gets converted to an abscess.

Red infarcts are seen

  • with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
  • in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone
  • in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone
  • in tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow
  • when the flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction)

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be associated with the blood picture shown in the peripheral smear given below?

questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows schistocytes and helmet cells suggesting hemolytic anemia. Defective DNA cross-link repair is unlikely to cause hemolytic anemia. 

Defective DNA cross-link repair causes a rare, autosomal recessive disorder called Fanconi anemia. It is characterized by aplastic anemia, developmental anomalies, leukemia, and increased hypersensitivity to chemotherapeutic agents. Aplastic anemia features a hypocellular bone marrow resulting in primary hematopoietic failure and pancytopenia.

Schistocytes and helmet cells are commonly seen in microangiopathic and macroangiopathic hemolytic conditions caused due to trauma to red cells. Artificial mechanical heart valves (option A) are the most commonly implicated cause. The shear forces produced by turbulent blood flow and pressure gradients across damaged valves account for hemolysis.

Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is seen in:

  1. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  2. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
  3. Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
  4. Malignant hypertension
  5. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  6. Metastatic cancer

The common pathology behind these conditions includes the presence of a microvascular lesion that leads to luminal narrowing and subsequent shear stress that mechanically injures the passing red cells. Traumatic damage of red cells leads to intravascular hemolysis and the appearance of fragmented red cells (schistocytes). Burr cells, helmet cells, and triangle cells may also be seen in these conditions.

Other options:

Option B: Recent attack of infectious gastroenteritis may be a possible cause since infection with Shiga toxin-producing E. coli can result in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

Option C: TTP is caused due to ADAMTS13 deficiency. This plasma enzyme is also called vWF metalloprotease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient with cystic fibrosis presents with a chronic airway disease by Pseudomonas. How does inflammation, in this case, differ from the usual process?

choices.text: Neutrophils are continuously recruited for several days.
Neutrophils are not the first cells to arrive.
Neutrophils are not present in an inflammatory  infiltrate.
Neutrophils remain present for a shorter duration than normal.

questions.solution:
In Pseudomonas infection, Neutrophils are continuously recruited for several days. This is an exception to the usual process of inflammation where neutrophils are short-lived, they undergo apoptosis and disappear within 24-48 hours. The nature of the leukocyte infiltrate varies with the age of the inflammatory response and the type of stimulus.

Other exceptions:

In a viral infection, lymphocytes may be the first cells to arrive. 

Some hypersensitivity reactions are dominated by activated lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells.

Helminthic infections and allergic reactions have eosinophils as the main cell type.

questions.text: A young man presents with vomiting, nausea, and epigastric pain. He has been on proton-pump inhibitors for the past year. An endoscopy revealed multiple well-circumscribed polyps with a smooth surface, located on the gastric body and fundus. Shown below is a histopathological image of the polyp. Which of the following is this condition most likely associated with?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and site of the polyps are highly suggestive of fundic gland polyps. This condition is most likely associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Fundic gland polyps usually occur at a mean age of 50 years. They are commonly found in the gastric body and fundus. These polyps may occur sporadically with proton-pump inhibitor use or due to mutation of the APC gene. APC gene mutation is also associated with familial adenomatous polyposis and hence is a possible risk factor for the development of fundic gland polyps.

They may be asymptomatic or associated with nausea, vomiting, or epigastric pain. Dysplasia, and even cancer, may occur in FAP-associated fundic gland polyps. But sporadic polyps due to proton pump inhibitors use do not progress to neoplastic conditions. Another gastric polyp associated with FAP is gastric adenoma.

Histological image of fundic gland polyp showing cystically dilated, irregular glands lined by flattened parietal and chief cells. Inflammation is typically absent or minimal.

Other options: 

Option A: Chronic gastritis - Multiple, smooth, hyperplastic, or inflammatory polyps that are <1 cm in size occur in chronic gastritis. On histology, they show irregular, cystically dilated, and elongated foveolar glands with edematous lamina propria. Variable degrees of inflammation are present.

Option B: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome - It is due to the presence of gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors in the small intestine or pancreas. The oxyntic mucosa of the stomach is thickened due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Option C: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome - This is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. Histology shows a characteristic branching or arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by a normal-appearing intestinal epithelium. The following image shows the histology of a polyp in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: A 5 yr old girl is brought to you by her mother, stating that the girl drinks a lot of water. Physical examination shows a slight protrusion of her eyes. An X-ray of the head reveals the presence of multiple lytic bone lesions involving the calvarium and base of her skull. A biopsy of the skull lesion shows grooved nuclei and moderately abundant pale cytoplasm as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this girl?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and biopsy specimen suggests that the girl has Hand Schuller Christian disease.

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH):

A spectrum of clinical diseases associated with the proliferation of Langerhans cells. These cells contain distinctive granules, seen on electron microscopy – Rod shaped tennis racket or Birbeck granules. On light microscopy, Langerhans cells with folded or grooved nuclei and moderately abundant pale cytoplasm are mixed with a few eosinophils are seen.

Hand-Schuller-Christian disease (Multifocal LCH) – Common in 2 - 6 years of life. The characteristic triad consists of:

  • Bony lytic skull lesions
  • Exophthalmos
  • Diabetes insipidus

Letterer-Siwe disease (Acute disseminated LCH) - Affects children before 3 yrs of age. Features include:

  • Seborrheic lesions,
  • Anaemia, thrombocytopenia
  • Recurrent infections
  • Clinical course is usually rapidly fatal

Unifocal Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophillic granuloma)is a localized form of histiocytosis, a benign lesion of proliferating Langerhans' cells. It is the least severe of the histiocytosis syndromes, and is characterized by lytic lesions of one or more bones. Seen in older patients, mostly affecting the skeletal system.
